description.en:
The course introduces a relatively new field of study —ecosemiotics. Ecosemiotic research concentrates on the relations between natural and cultural environment and on the cultural mechanisms, which create and/ or balance environmental conflicts. 
The essentials of ecosemiotics are discussed in the course by comparing the discipline with other academic fields investigating the man-nature relationship (e.g. cultural ecology, human ecology, human geography). A "history of ideas approach" is used to demonstrate the development of environmentalist ideas in Western cultures.
In addition to the theoretical and practical uses of ecosemiotics, also basic knowledge of ecology is provided along with the introduction of the main environmental problems and their cultural sources.
description.et: Käesolev kursus tutvustab võrdlemisi uut uurimisvaldkonda - ökosemiootikat. Ökosemiootika peamisteks küsimusteks on looduse ja kultuurikeskkonna suhete interpreteerimine, keskkonnakonflikte tekitavad ja neid tasakaalustavad kultuurimehhanismid. Ökosemiootika olemuse üle arutlemiseks võrreldes distsipliini teise inimese ja looduse suhtele keskenduvate valdkondadega (nt. kultuuriökoloogia, inimökoloogia, inimgeograafia jt). Lääne kultuuri keskkonnateadliku mõtte arenguloo tutvustamiseks tuginetakse „ideede ajaloo lähenemisele". Lisaks ökosemiootika teooriale, kirjeldusmudelitele ja rakendusvõimalustele tutvustatakse loengus ökoloogia põhialuseid, inimese ja looduse suhte tüüpe ning tähtsamaid keskkonnaprobleeme ja nende kultuurilisi allikaid.

objectives.en: To introduce the theoretical grounds of ecosemiotics as well as its applications and key-authors; to provide a survey of the development of environmentalist thinking in the West and to discuss several modern understandings of man's place in the ecosystem.
objectives.et: Tutvustada ökosemiootika teoreetilisi aluseid ning selle rakendamisvõimalusi ning võtmeautoreid. Anda ülevaade keskkonnateadliku mõtte arengust läänes ning arutleda eriilmeliste kaasaegsete seisukohtade üle inimese kohast ökosüsteemis.

learning_outcomes.en: The student, who has passed the course:
1)	explains how have today's most critical ecological problems come into being and what has been the role of cultural and philosophical traditions in creating those problems;
learning_outcomes.et: 1) mõistab ja oskab selgitada, kuidas on tekkinud tänapäeva kõige tõsisemad ökoloogilised probleemid ning millised filosoofilised ja kultuurilised traditsioonid on nende algallikateks;

learning_outcomes.en: 2)	is familiar with the theoretical grounds of ecosemiotics and with its methods of analysis and can apply them independently;
learning_outcomes.et: 2) teab ökosemiootika teoreetilisi aluseid ja analüüsimeetodeid ning oskab neid iseseisvalt rakendada;

learning_outcomes.en: 1)	has an overview of the most substantial environmentalist authors and their works.
learning_outcomes.et: 3) omab ülevaadet keskkonnamõtte olulisematest autoritest ning nende kesksetest töödest.

description.et:
A brief popularising introduction to some form of new nature or some underrepresented environmental process, using multisensory media (e.g, a video or photo essay, a guided walk, etc), including a creative as well as an academic component
 (done as a group work of 3-4 persons)

Short presentation: the topic should fall within one of the three blocks of the course: 1) Multispecies interactions and diversity 2) Representations and values of the environment 3) Environmental history and modelling the future of human-environment relations (the same topic should  be later expanded into an individual essay)

Final essay (5-6 pg) 
The topic should fall within one of the three blocks of the course: 1) Multispecies interactions and diversity 2) Representations and values of the environment 3) Environmental history and modelling the future of human-environment relations (the same topic should  be later expanded into an individual essay)
The essay should: 1) use some empirical data; 2) entail an explicitly ecosemiotic component, but may also combine approaches from some other fields of environmental humanities.
The criteria of assessment:
-The delimitation and relevance of the topic for the course 
-The use of relevant sources and proof of their relevance for the topic 
-Logical argumentation and structure
-Novelty
-the integration of the theoretical concepts and empirical data
-the visibility of an ecosemiotic stance
 -Scientifically correct presentation of the text (clear demarcation of your own thoughts and those of the others, a unified reference system and everything else that is proper to the scientific text)

A- the topic well delimited, the arguments well grounded and logically presented, very good integration of empirical sources and theoretical stance, an ecosemiotic stance visible, text formatted according to scientific standards
B- the arguments well grounded and logically presented, connections exist between the empirical and theoretical part,  minor gaps in the delimitation of the topic, structuring of the text or the ecosemiotic framing
C- the topic does not have a clear focus, relevant sources used, gaps in argumentation or structuring of the text, ecosemiotic stance there, but not integral to the topic, 
D- the topic lacks focus, larger gaps in argumentation or structuring the text, the empirical and theoretical parts distant from one another, ecosemiotic framing hardly there, scientifically correct presentation of the text
E-the topic lacks focus, the argumentation is poor and the structure not fully graspable, gaps in the scientific presentation of the text, empirical part and theoretical stance don't fit together, 
F-no traces of logical argumentation, originality or academic structuring principles, concerning both the form as well as the content, topic not relevant for the course and without focus, no attempts to unite the theoretical concepts and empirical data
Feedback to one essay from the course participant (1-2 pg)

description.et:
Introduction to environmental humanities and ecosemiotics

The reasons for the rise of environmental humanities at the end of the 20th century; the role of humanities research in targeting environmental issues; different subdisciplines of environmental humanities; examples of the combination of natural scientific and humanities approaches in addressing environmental/social problems
The place of ecosemiotics in environmental humanities; cultural and biological ecosemiotics (K. Kull, W. Nöth et al.); signification and communication as ecosemiotic processes; ecosemiotic case studies

Block I Multispecies interactions 

Ways of being with other beings

The typology of human--non-human relations (P. Descola); historical ideas about animism (E. Tylor; E. Durkheim); "new animism" and reestablishment of the common ground for human-nonhuman interactions (I. Hallowell, N. Bird-David, T. Ingold); perspectivism (Viveiros de Castro; R. Willerslev) and its semiotic constituents; sign use in interspecific interactions (E: Kohn)

Ecosemiotics

Readings: 
Maran, T; Kull, K. 2014. Ecosemiotics: main principles and current developments. Geografiska Annaler: Series B, Human Geography 96 (1): 41-50

Lindström, K., Palang, H., & Kull, K. (2013). Semiotics of landscape. In P. Howard, I. Thompson, & E. Waterton (Eds.), The Routledge companion to landscape studies (pp. 97-107). London: Routledge.

Human-animal relations: the wild, the domesticated and the tame 

The principles of distinguishing between different kinds of human-animal relations; classification of animals as a ground for human values and behavior; specific relations with animals and  the structure of society;  drawing distinctions between the wild, the domesticated and the tame on the example of wolves and dogs.

Biodiversity and cultural diversity

Historical changes in the key topics of nature conservation; the coming about of biodiversity and cultural diversity as the ultimate value for conservation; why does biodiversity matter; measures and models of biodiversity; potential semiotic measures of biodiversity; correlation and co-formation of cultural and natural diversity
A seminar with student presentations on multispecies interactions

Seminar on multispecies interactions

Readings:
 Kohn, Eduardo 2005. Runa Realism: Upper Amazonian Attitudes to Nature Knowing. Ethnos, 70, 171-196.
Mullet, Timothy; Farina, Almo 2017. The Acoustic Habitat Hypothesis: An Ecoacoustics Perspective on Species Habitat Selection. Biosemiotics 10(3):1-18

Block II Representations and values of environment

What and who gets represented and what not from the environment; the limits and possibilites of cultural texts in representing environmental events and processes.

Environmental ethics

Major strands of environmental ethics and arguments for grounding values: anthropocentrism and biocentrism; utilitarian and deontological approaches; the connections between semiotic research and environmental ethics

Seminar
Readings: Alf Hornborg, Andreas Malm 2014. The geology of mankind? A
critique of the Anthropocene narrative. The Anthropocene Review
 1(1) 62-69
Student presentations on representations and values of environment
Guest lecture

Block III 

Environmental history & modelling of future human-environment relations

The rise and fall of civilizations as the core narratives of environmental history; modelling future human-environment relations based on the historical relations; unpredictability and complexity of environmental historical processes

Nature conservation and novel ecosystems

Preserving the old vs letting the new develop; novel ecosystems and biodiversity;
Presentation of creative academic works on novel environments and on the unrepresented environmental processes

Unequal exchange

Biological companions of the human colonizers; the "portmanteau biota" and the Neo-Europe (A. Crosby; reasons of unequal exchange between the colonising and colonized; the resource curse

Text: McNeill, John R. 1999. "Ecology, Epidemics and Empires: Environmental Change and the Geopolitics of Tropical America, 1600-1825." Environment and History 5: 175-184
Seminar with student presentations on environmental history and modelling of future human-environment relations
An urban ecosemiotic walk in Tartu
